thread.title: Tourists wrestle in the mud to celebrate South Korea's Boryeong Mud Festival
thread.title_full: Tourists wrestle in the mud to celebrate South Korea's Boryeong Mud Festival | Daily Mail Online

author: Jake Polden For Mailonline
title: Tourists wrestle in the mud to celebrate South Korea's Boryeong Mud Festival
text:
22 shares 1
View
comments
Tourists in South Korea joined locals at the 18th Boryeong Mud Festival and left the celebrations more than a little dirty.
The activities, which took place on Daecheon beach, saw festival-goers partaking in everything from a mud football match to a mud race and a mud-pool wrestling competition.
There was also a giant mudslide for both tourists and locals to enjoy and attendees were able to get coloured mud body paintings.
Tourists and locals get dirty at mud festival in South Korea Festival-goers took part in everything from a mud football match to a mud race and a mud-pool wrestling competition
Tourists and locals were able to get coloured mud body paintings and play on a giant mudslide
A tourist to the event said: ‘We are here with a group of university students, a group of 50 or so, and so far it's pretty great.
‘I mean it's like a little kids' summer festival but for grownups and it's great.
‘People are drunk and everyone is going to go and bounce around and get all painted up. There is nothing wrong, nothing to complain.’
The mud used for the event is brought in from the Boryeong mud flat as it is said to contain properties beneficial for the skin and is rich in minerals
A tourist described the event as being like a little kids' summer festival but for grownups
The festival started out as a marketing tool for a cosmetic company hoping to attract tourists to Boryeong.
It has since achieved international fame and last year over three million people were in attendance.
The mud used for the event is brought in from the Boryeong mud flat as it is said to contain properties beneficial for the skin and is rich in minerals.
The mud festival has achieved international fame and last year over three million people were in attendance
